page.title: 09CHANGING TIMES.
page.content: Farming in East Preston. Mr. Francis, whose father became head gardener at Kingston Manor in 1920, told us there used to be about 400 sheep in the fields locally before 1939-45 war. Cattle and pigs were kept. 20 shire horses worked the land. People bought their milk from the farms and walked everywhere, though a few had horses and traps. Farm labourers worked 15-16 hours a day in summer getting up at 4 a.m. In the school holidays children earned pocket money by helping with the harvest. That, explained Mr. Francis, was how he became the proud owner of a Â£4.00 bicycle. Now Kingston Farm with 30 sheep and a small herd of cows is the only one of the 4 farms left. Originally the farmer had a little shop. Crispa Cress and Langmead's now work the land.
